lexUnit.name: tolerant.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: showing a willingness to allow or endure a disagreeable behavior or person.

sentence.text: Fortunately , there is a more tolerant attitude towards other religions in most parts of the world today .

Gandhi 's tolerant attitude to religions , which will be dealt with in the following chapter , is an indication that he does not consider any religion to have a monopoly of Truth and that includes Hinduism .

A third feature underlying the courts ' tolerant attitude to managerial failure is their belief , at least historically , that mismanagement can , and should , be controlled by means of shareholder supervision .
They were in general tolerant in their attitude to the Protestant Dissenters .

Morse was usually reasonably tolerant about fellow-tipplers , and indeed occasionally rather enjoyed the company of slightly tipsy sirens ; but the sight of this fellow pathetically fighting to extricate a wallet from an inner pocket , and then forking out and handing over three £10 notes — such a sight filled even Morse with mild disgust .

The DGM felt quite comfortable about this and also tolerant about the trusts ' sometimes misplaced attempts to establish their autonomy : " After escaping from the nest they go around flapping their wings and hissing at people " .
The Masai are pretty tolerant in these matters in my experience .
And we do n't seem to be very tolerant in our society , of people who are a bit different .
Being Irish herself , and the sister of a man who had gone mad with syphilis , she was rather more tolerant of Warnie 's foibles than he was of hers .
It is not that most of the people of southern Ireland are supportive or even tolerant of the terrorists .
If only we humans were less ambitious , and more tolerant of one another , then there would n't be a need for arms at all , and every mother 's child would be safe .
We must be tolerant of others who do not have our gifts or drive as each of us can only perform to the extent of our own personal capacity .

I have always found the staff honest , trustworthy , intensely loyal and hard-working , generally very tolerant of all extremes of consumer behaviour , and therefore the best asset and advertisement any business can have .
It is true , certainly , that Constantine was tolerant towards Christianity .
Records show the local constabulary to have been remarkably tolerant towards prostitutes and apparently sensitive to the sexual practices of the poor .
I think it 's even made us more tolerant towards other people . "
I think in the old days people were more tolerant towards each other .

In time , the kingdom of Babylon was overthrown and the Israelites were permitted to return to Jerusalem in 539 b.c. The city was now under the more tolerant rule of the Persians , but rebuilding was slow work .
